title: Waterfalls
text:
Throughout Iceland, there are many glaciers; the 3 largest are Vatnajökull, Langjökull, and Hofsjökull, but there are hundreds of other smaller glaciers all over the country, covering about 10% of the land (around 10,400 square kilometers). As a result, there are also waterfalls all over the place! Here are a few that we visited during our trip:




Öxarárfoss 



Öxarárfoss, with plunge pool and start of runoff


The first waterfall we visited in Iceland was Öxarárfoss, inheriting it’s name from the Öxará river from which it flows.



The rest of the runoff stream


This waterfall is located in the Þingvellir National Park, which was the site of the Alþing, the annual parliament of Iceland from the year 930 until the last session held at Þingvellir in 1798. Since 1881, the parliament has been located within Alþingishúsið in Reykjavík.



Us in front of Öxarárfoss






Gullfoss




Barnafoss




Hraunfossar




Fossfjörður




Misc Dynjandi 1




Misc Dynjandi 2




Misc Dynjandi 3




Hundafoss




Misc Dynjandi 4




Dynjandi




Bunárfoss

title: Closeread example
text:
What is Quarto? What is R?




Quarto is an open-source scientific and technical publishing system.




Quarto lets you author documents using plain text markdown in your favorite editor.




1




2




3




4




You can use quarto documents with R.




R is a free software environment for statistical computing and graphics.




R is available on Unix, MacOS, and Windows.

title: Iceland 2025
text:
This is a digital scrapbook for our trip to Iceland on June 16th, 2025 to June 26th, 2025.
This website is best viewed on a computer, or in landscape mode on your phone or tablet.

Sections

Route
Waterfalls
Animals
Plants

Made using Quarto and Closeread.

title: Route
text:
The driving route we took through the country using Alex’s road maps. Maybe a section of scary routes at the end with elevation.




June 17th: Drove to Reykjavik and walked around




June 18th: Drive to Thingvellir, Geysir, and Gulfoss, then back to Reykjavik




June 19th: Walk around Reykjavik




June 20th: Drive to Glymur waterfall and The Cave tour, then to Gil Guesthouse




June 21st: Drive to Red sand beaches and Latrabjarg, then to Harbour Inn Guesthouse




June 22nd: Drive to Dyjandi waterfall and Isafjordur, then to Einarshusid Guesthouse




June 23th: Drive to Holmavik, then to Dala Hotel




June 24th: Drive to Grindavik and the Rekyjanes, then to Northern Lights Inn




June 25th: Drive around the Reykjanes again and Fagradalsfjall volcano, then to Reykjavik




That’s all!














 Back to top
